Articles.Content:
The antennas and dishes as they are currently implemented in the game leave something to be desired. They are badly balanced towards each other and there isn't much reason to use one over the other. Let's take the smallest antenna, the Communotron 16. It is light and requires the least amount of power to transmit scientific data. It's low mass allows it to be placed asymmetrically and its power requirements won't drain your batteries too heavily. It's only downside is that it's slower in transmitting. Then there's the Communotron 88-88. It unfolds into a large dish, is five times as heavy as the 16 and requires twice as much power when broadcasting. Luckily - I say sarcastically - it's somewhat more than twice as fast. The third part, the DTS-M1, is not much better. It takes up more space than the other two, is slightly heavier than the 88-88 and is in between the 16 and 88-88 in terms of transmission speed and power cost.

As should be apparent, there's little reason not to only use the Communotron 16. It's the lightest, the least power-hungry and only takes up a small space on your craft. It's only drawback? It's marginally slower than the other two. To show how insignificant that is I made a table. The largest experiment in terms of transmission size is the Atmosphere Analysis (the old avionics nosecone part). It is 200 so-called Mits large.

[table=width: 500, class: grid]

[tr]

[td]Part[/td]

[td]Transmission Time[/td]

[td]ElectricalCharge Consumption[/td]

[/tr]

[tr]

[td]Communotron 16[/td]

[td]40 seconds[/td]

[td]5000[/td]

[/tr]

[tr]

[td]Communotron 88-88[/td]

[td]18 seconds[/td]

[td]22222[/td]

[/tr]

[tr]

[td]Comms DTS-M1[/td]

[td]30 seconds[/td]

[td]10000[/td]

[/tr]

[/table]

As you can see the amount of time is pitiful compared to the increased power cost. It gets even worse when you consider that the Atmosphere Analysis is an outlier with its 200 Mit size. The average of all the other experiments is about 20 Mits. The difference between the antennas then barely becomes noticeable (just divide the results of the table above by ten).

A simple solution to this would be to make the antennas that are heavier, be more power efficient. Not draining your batteries is a big advantage and much more important than speed (which in almost every situation will be irrelevant). I would also argue to make the DTS-M1 lighter than the 88-88. It's smaller when unfolded and in the other stats is also in between the 88-88 and the 16.

The above solution solves the problem of the first unlocked part (in career) being the better option. But what to do once you've unlocked all the antenna parts? Then the 16 and DTS-M1 are generally less useful than the 88-88. This can be solved by introducing range. The mod AntennaRange does a great job of showing how wonderful such a thing can be. All the antennas have a range. The 16 can transmit data back to Kerbin from a Keosynchronous orbit. If you want to transmit something from the Mun or Minmus, you'll need a DTS-M1. Want to go even further, then you'll have to use the 88-88. Additionally, antennas can act as simple relays. Nothing complicated, like RemoteTech, but a simple 'if there is chain of antennas in each other's range that can connect to Kerbin, then I can send my scientific data'. This allows fun situations in which you can have a light-weight Communotron 16 on your rover on the surface of Duna connect with the heavier 88-88 on an orbiting probe. This is similar to how for example Curiosity communicates to Earth using the 2001 Mars Odyssey orbiter as a relay.

It would be nice to adjust the time by adjusting the packet size. That way when you get further on, and you are sending bigger and bigger blocks of data, it becomes a significant advantage to use a larger antenna.

The other thing that should be adjusted is having a separate charge consumption to deploy, then an additional cost per each packet.

Finally, one more improvement is that there should be an option to lock an antenna in it's deployed state. (A good idea on a space station or probe, but a bad idea on a lander or rover for the reason of damage in the event of a minor crash.)

Edited March 13, 2014 by Ruedii
clarification
Yes, packet size is also a way to differentiate them as KSP currently uses the same size for all the antenna.

I play ksp under the assumption that all part balance is place holder, with the primary goal of Squad to not have parts with stats that would get in the way of playing the game; for now they'd rather have parts be to easy or not make sense relative to other parts, as opposed to it being to difficult. Solar panel stats being a prime example.

Until Squad makes serious work of part balance, i feel free to adjust parts stats as i see fit.

IMHO, the 88-88, being a directional dish, should use far less electricity than the omnidirectional 16. Perhaps only 10% of the power at longer ranges. The antennas should not have a maximum range. After all, we have used an omni antenna to control the Galileo spacecraft to Jupiter. It was just a much reduced speed and much higher power. (Galileo was the one where the dish got stuck during launch and could not deploy. We still got many beautiful pictures back, but only a few percent of what could have been possible with the dish.)

There are mods such as RemoteTech for those who want the challenge of extra realism, but the vanilla 88-88 should still have a realistic advantage over a simple whip antenna.

Since the DTS-M1 is also a somewhat directional design, but is smaller than the 88-88 and not a full dish, it's power requirement should be somewhere between the other two.

Edited May 6, 2014 by brianorca

Yes, packet size is also a way to differentiate them as KSP currently uses the same size for all the antenna.

Packet size is usually a consistent size in data communication. It's enough to just have different electricity and time variables for each packet.

As nice as range and directional transmitting would be, you would need many more different type of antennae for it (more than 3 at least). I think just a simple solution currently is weight and effciency. Make the 88-88's model bigger, make it less efficient but faster than the 16, and make it weigh 1+ tons; this would discourage people from using it on small probes, but then it would be slower transmissions (you could even make transmissions take longer when further away, then make the 88-88 really heavy); make the 16 the most efficient and the lightest, but the slowest, and then just put the DTS-M1 in the middle.

Transmission times in general should be longer, but actually have more packets in them, making transmissions much longer and require much more energy, so efficiency and time are factors you have to balance. Also, a data increase from a science lab would increase the amount of packets in the transmission, making it take even longer.

Also, I'd change the science % from transmissions to something like this:

Surface Sample= 25%, 50% with Science Lab (WSL)

Materials Lab= 25%, 50% WSL

Mystery Goo= 25%, 50% WSL

Seismic Scan= 50%, 75% WSL

Gravity Scan= 50%, 75% WSL

Atmospheric NoseCone Scan= 50%, 75% WSL

Barometer Scan= 75%, 100% WSL

Temperature Scan= 75%, 100% WSL

EVA Report still 100%

Crew Report still 100%

As nice as range and directional transmitting would be, you would need many more different type of antennae for it (more than 3 at least). I think just a simple solution currently is weight and effciency. Make the 88-88's model bigger, make it less efficient but faster than the 16, and make it weigh 1+ tons; this would discourage people from using it on small probes, but then it would be slower transmissions (you could even make transmissions take longer when further away, then make the 88-88 really heavy); make the 16 the most efficient and the lightest, but the slowest, and then just put the DTS-M1 in the middle.

If speed is the only factor, then there's absolutely no reason to use the 88-88, as I have never had a time crunch when sending data. The larger, heavier part should be more energy (electric) efficient, not less. Otherwise why bother carrying it? It would also mirror real NASA tech, where the small omni antenna must be run on high power, while the directional dish can still work with small amounts of power. The Voyager 2 spacecraft, at the far reaches of our solar system, can be heard despite transmitting only 20 watts of power, due to it's dish.

I think a good way to balance these parts would be to make the efficiency of their transmission, as in how much science you get from transmitting, dependent on both which antenna you use and how far from Kerbin you are. As an example, all of the antenna might be equally good around Kerbin and on the Mun, but once you go to say Duna you might find that the Communotron 16 gets you 10%-20% less science than the others. At Jool you might again find that the Communotron 88-88 gives you the best performance, making up for its weight and higher power consumption, and so on. I think this would allow for better balancing and give the antennas a greater degree of specialization.

Edited May 7, 2014 by SofusRud
